reference.title: Formatting expectations
reference.shortdesc: DITA is a standard that supports the creation of human-readable content. Accordingly, DITA defines fundamental document components. Since there is a reasonable expectation that such document components be rendered consistently, we suggest the following formatting conventions.

draft-comment.author: Kristen J Eberlein
draft-comment.p: This topic need to be edited for style and consistency.

row.entry: Apply bold highlighting to the contents of the chdeschd element.

entry.p: If choice table does not contain a header row, processors typically auto-generate labels for the columns in the choice table.
Unless the keycol attribute is set to 0, processors typically apply bold highlighting to the contents of the "Option" column.

row.entry: Apply bold highlighting to the contents of the choptionhd element.
Separate uicontrol elements with a character to represent the menu cascade.
Surround the contents of the numcharref element with a leading ampersand (&) and a trailing semi-colon (;).
Surround the contents of the numcharref element with a leading percentage sign (%) and a trailing semi-colon (;).
Enclose the contents of the screen element with a box to suggest a computer display screen.
Highlight the keyboard shortcut with underlining.
Render steps with only a single step as a paragraph. Render two or more steps as an ordered list.
Surround the contents of the textentity element with a leading ampersand (&) and a trailing semi-colon (;).
Precede the contents of the xmlatt element with a commercial at symbol (@) or equals character (=) .
Surround the contents of the xmlelement element with leading (<) and trailing (>) angle brackets.
